When I first heard of the mRNA vaccines, I was hesitant to get one. Then I realized that mRNA vaccines would be the most effective method to counter future epidemics. Globalization has increased the likelihood of a quickly developing epidemic. mRNA vaccines can be designed and implemented quickly. As soon as the Covid vaccine was released, I received one, knowing full well that I was a test subject. In my opinion, I was a test subject for a good cause. My grandmother barely survived the 1918 flu; in her 90's, she still remembered it as the worst headache of her life. In my 40's, I lost hearing in my right ear because of a viral infection.  I have two friends who had long Covid; their recovery took years, not days or weeks. Viruses can cause permanent damage to your body. Patients who survived polio in later life have to contend with post-polio syndrome.

We need to support US public health efforts and medical research, both basic and applied.  Recent research suggests that getting the shingles vaccine may decrease the risk of dementia associated with aging.  Would you get vaccinated if there was evidence that it decreased your risk of cancer? 

We need a trusted global disease monitoring network. Our systems aren't perfect, but they are better than the alternative. China and Russia also developed Covid vaccines that were not as effective as the mRNA vaccines developed in the US and Europe.

I am a recently retired academic oncologist spent all my career was working in a a tertiary level teaching hospital in an oncology service. My job that involved treating patients, training new specialists and a major component of participation in ongoing clinical trials of new agents  in the fight against cancers. 

In that last 30 years a revolution has begun with the advent of the so called biological agents all targeted at specific molecular biologic pathways common in many types of cancers. 
The concept of making and using mRNA vaccines started off as research into new better ways to treat cancers and pretty soon it was understood that mRNA vaccines and the technology behind them had a much wider use across many other fields of medicine. 

World-wide there are two statutory bodies whose approval of any new agent is essential before that agent can be used - one is the US FDA and the other the European EMA. 

The approval of either agency for use of any new agent in ALL highly developed, developed, and developing  nations and both were fully trusted. 

Sadly trust in the regulators in the US is now gone and already in the US whole systems that took decades to build and to hone to perfection are collapsing and the thousands expert personnel that worked in them are simply leaving 

I can see already that the American and worldwide  academic scientific community, and the major pharmaceutical companies are discarding looking to the FDA for guidance and approval.. 
From now on it will be the EMA that sets the direction and the pace of medical research.

I don‚Äôt like posts like this because they often miss the real point behind people‚Äôs fears and concerns about vaccines. Yes, it‚Äôs true that an inactivated vaccine is essentially a killed virus‚Äîjust pieces of it. But even though the virus isn‚Äôt alive, the vaccine still contains antigens, which are the parts your immune system reacts to.

When your body detects those antigens, it responds as if a real virus has entered. That immune activation can cause side effects ranging from mild soreness and fatigue to more noticeable symptoms like fever. Dr. Mike does a great job highlighting the difference between a researcher and a medical doctor. 

A medical doctor reads (usually only the conclusion) what the researchers have published, and regurgitates it.

A researcher reads the entire study.  Meaning they read the abstract, introduction, methods, results, and discussion.  They carefully scrutinize the data to see if there are any apparent flaws that jump out.  Then below the ‚Äúdiscussion‚Äù (or ‚Äúresults‚Äù if there is no ‚Äúdiscussion‚Äù) they take note at the references cited.  And wait... there‚Äôs more!  Then a researcher will read all the articles that each citation came from.  This again includes the abstract, introduction, methods, results, discussion, and references.  They repeat this until they can verify beyond a shadow of a doubt that the accuracy of that first study that they read stands up to critique, and no flaws are identified.

So let‚Äôs go back to comparing Dr. Mike‚Äôs profession to a researchers.  Dr. Mike, a medical doctor,  is an applied science profession.  They take what the researchers publish and apply it in a narrow scope to their type of practice.  Whereas a researcher has a doctorate (Ph.d) in all the complex nuances and tiniest little details in their field.  They are truly experts in their respective fields.  

Now let‚Äôs apply all this to Flu vaccines, and whether Dr. Mike is qualified and/or knowledgeable about all the complexities that go into creating any particular Flu vaccine.

Based on the fact that Dr. Mike does not cite studies to substantiate any of his claims, let alone discuss (and provide sources) each individual ingredient in a given Flu vaccine, it is safe to say that he is simply regurgitating what he has been ‚Äútaught‚Äù without subjecting it to multiple layers of scrutiny.  

Simply put, Dr. Mike (and any other MD who doesn‚Äôt dive into the research) are in many ways no more than highly educated sales associates for the pharmaceutical industry.  And in all fairness, a practicing full time medical doctor likely does not have the time to dive into research in the same capacity a professional researcher would.  But let‚Äôs not pretend that it‚Äôs okay to spew out commercialized scripts about Flu vaccines, like Dr. Mike is doing.  

At the very least, he should recite a disclaimer in the beginning of this video (and every other video he‚Äôs made) that the information he provides is based on his frame of reference, and is in no way a substitution for carefully reading peer reviewed literature on each ingredient in the vaccine.  On the other end of the spectrum, if he wanted to be as accurate as possible, he should take this video down.

To all who are curious about whether or not the Flu vaccine is safe, I highly recommend reading peer reviewed studies on each individual ingredient that‚Äôs present in any given vaccine.  I would also highly recommend to research the sad history of accidental contaminations or various vaccine supplies.  Also research the role ‚Äúcell lines‚Äù play in the creation and production of vaccines, and how inadvertent transmission of viruses from the animal tissue that cell lines are grown in occur more often than the government likes to admit.

Not to needlessly nitpick, but the animation of the globe makes it seem like all of Africa and even parts of North America and Europe are in the southern hemisphere. In reality, only a minority of Africa (a bit less than half, iirc) is in the southern hemisphere, and none of North America, Europe or mainland Asia. The only large landmasses to have their majority below the equator are South America and Australia, with significant portions of the Indonesian Archipelago being below as well. Anyway, I realize this is probably an odd result of combining an aesthetically pleasing display of the globe, and wanting a simple infographic line horiziontally across the animation. Again, not necessarily a huge issue for the purposes of the video, but it could send an incorrect impression to people who aren't too familiar with geography.

The common cold is ancient, existing as long as humans have, with evidence in ancient texts like the Ebers Papyrus (16th century BCE) and ancient DNA, suggesting some cold-causing viruses predate Homo sapiens, possibly evolving 700,000 years ago, meaning these sniffles have troubled humanity for millennia. 
Evidence of its ancient history:
Ancient Texts: Descriptions of cold-like symptoms and remedies appear in the Ebers Papyrus, one of the oldest medical documents. 
Ancient DNA: DNA from cold-related viruses found in ancient human teeth suggests they've affected people for at least 31,000 years, with some viruses potentially older than our species. 
Early Communities: Colds have been present since humans lived in communities, with Chinese medicine using plant-based remedies for blocked noses for thousands of years. 
What we know today:
Viral Cause: The common cold is caused by many viruses, primarily rhinoviruses, which are very common and hard to create a vaccine for due to constant mutation. 
Symptoms & Spread: It causes inflammation in the nose and throat, spreading easily through airborne droplets or contact with contaminated surfaces. 
In essence, while the specific viruses causing colds have evolved, the ailment itself is a long-standing companion to humanity, with roots stretching back hundreds of thousands of years.

(including encephalomyelitis and transverse myelitis), facial palsy (Bell‚Äôs palsy), optic 
neuritis/neuropathy, brachial neuritis, syncope (shortly after vaccination), dizziness, paresthesia 
‚Ä¢ Vascular Disorders: Vasculitis, vasodilatation/flushing
